entry.title: Combined summary - Fw: Quote on BIP 16
entry.summary: The discussion revolves around the size of a Bitcoin address when encoding a script. A forum post describes an address that is only 77 bytes, which appears too small for two public keys when encoded. Gregory Maxwell suggests using pay to script_hash (P2SH) to avoid needing longer addresses. Gavin clarifies that he meant 70 characters, not bytes. Without P2SH, the only option available for personal choice is to use some form of "P2S", pay-to-script, where the address encodes a full script specification for the sender instead of encoding its hash. However, this approach has several problems, including vulnerability to invisible substitution, responsibility for fees related to enlarged transactions, creation of another input vector for non-trivial data, and complicated release rules in transaction outputs.In contrast, P2SH reduces output sizes to the absolute minimum without inflating the total data size. It is a more efficient solution that avoids the issues associated with P2S. Overall, P2SH provides a better option for encoding scripts in Bitcoin addresses, ensuring optimal efficiency and avoiding potential vulnerabilities and complications associated with other solutions.
